thread.title: North East's digital sector could be harmed by Government's Brexit stance

author: Jonathon Manning
title: North East's digital sector could be harmed by Government's Brexit stance
text:
Business North East's digital sector could be harmed by Government's Brexit stance Digital Union has warned that failing to protect EU workers could lead to skilled workers leaving the sector Share Remain supporters near Park Lane in London (Image: PA) Share Get   
The growth of digital businesses in the North East could be held back by the Government’s stance on the status of EU nationals after Brexit , a campaign group has warned. 
Digital Union, which represents digital and creative businesses in the region, said that the recent boom in the sector had been made possible by companies being able to employ both UK and European staff with the right skills. 
Recent surveys have suggested many skilled workers from the EU are thinking of leaving Britain after last year’s referendum vote, sparking fears of a ‘brain drain’ from the country. 
Prime Minister Theresa May made an offer of EU citizens’ rights but the European Parliament’s lead Brexit negotiator Guy Verhofstadt said it risks creating “second-class citizenship” for Europeans working in the UK. Rachel Peacock, networks manager at Digital Union (Image: Unknown) 
Rachel Peacock, Digital Union’s networks manager, said: “The thought of highly-skilled EU workers potentially leaving the country over the next five years is worrying. 
“There are a substantial number of EU nationals within the creative digital sector who are significantly contributing to the growth and success of the sector and businesses within. 
“With the skills shortage challenge being as prevalent as it already is, it’s crucial that businesses within the UK have access to the wider talent pool, as, without this, we are only creating further barriers. 
“These highly skilled digital roles are more often than not, difficult to fill with UK nationals and until that changes with the further upskilling of our own domestic workforce, that issue is only going to worsen.” Read More North East businesses overwhelming want EU trading deals to remain unchanged 
Last month a survey of skilled workers at FTSE 250 companies found that more than half were either ‘highly likely’ or ‘quite likely’ to leave the UK before the outcome of the Brexit negotiations was known, with healthcare, technology, media and telecoms and financial services the sectors likely to be hardest hit. 
The difficult issue of the rights of EU citizens in the UK - and Britons on the continent - is one of the first tasks facing negotiators in the Brexit talks. 
Mrs May’s plan would allow EU nationals resident in the UK to apply for “settled status” - effectively guaranteeing them indefinite leave to remain in the country once Britain is out of the bloc. 
But MEPs have said there were “striking” differences between the UK’s offer and that set out by the EU’s chief negotiator Michel Barnier who “wants British people and Europeans to keep the same rights and the same level of protection they currently enjoy”. 
Award-winning Gateshead firm Atomhawk - which employs people from around the world - has added its voice to the debate and said that protecting EU workers’ rights was vital for the economy. Read More Marks and Spencer set to reveal boost in fashion sales buoyed by heatwave and late Easter 
Head of operations Tim Wilson said: “For businesses to succeed in an international economy they need access to international talent. Atomhawk’s team is drawn from the UK, EU and beyond. 
“Our ability to attract and retain the world’s best concept artists and designers has been crucial in helping us shape an award-winning team. 
“If the UK is to continue to appear ‘open for business’ the Government needs to reflect that in the way that it welcomes and retains talent from the EU and beyond.” Like us on Facebook
